components.title: Html
components.content:
You have received a link to this form because Environment Agency records show you hold a water quality permit.

The Environment Agency is reviewing these permits to make sure they have the correct details and comply with regulations introduced in 2016.

Completing this form helps us to check and update their records.

components.name: ZVksBs
components.title: Html
components.content:
Based on the information provided, you no longer need this water quality permit.

You should now:

  1. Continue to the end of the form to submit your answers.
  2. Complete a notification of surrender (opens in new tab) to surrender your permit.

pages.title: Your waste water discharge is exempt

components.name: xyrsZE
components.title: Html
components.content:
Based on the information you have given, your discharge is exempt. This means you do not need a permit.

You will need to continue to the end of the form to submit your answers.

The Environment Agency will then record this on the database. You will not need to do anything further.

pages.title: The Environment Agency needs more information

components.name: DhYbOo
components.title: Html
components.content:
Based on the information you have provided, you still need this permit. We will contact you to:

  • make sure your permit conditions reflect your discharge activity
  • vary your permit so that it meets current environmental permit regulations

You will need to continue to the end of the form to submit your answers.

pages.title: Do you have proof of transfer?
Proof of your permit transfer

components.name: ZGoolt
components.title: Html
components.content:
Upload evidence of the permit transfer, such as a certificate of holder document or transfer notice. This should show the operator of the permit and their contact details.

The Environment Agency will use this to correct their records.

If you cannot upload a version now:

  1. Continue to the end of this form to submit your answers.
  2. Send a copy of your proof of transfer by email to waterqualitypermitmodernisation@environment-agency.gov.uk (opens in new tab).

pages.title: Transferring a permit into your name

components.name: zBsrKI
components.title: Html
components.content:
To transfer the permit into your name, you will need to:

  1. Continue to the end of this form to submit your answers.
  2. Complete the Application for an environmental permit: part A, about you (opens in new tab) form.
  3. Complete the Notification for an environmental permit: part D1, notification of transfer (opens in new tab) form.

Both you and the existing permit holder will need to complete part D1.

The Environment Agency will send you a transfer notification once the permit is in your name.

If you cannot contact the permit holder

If you cannot contact the current permit holder, you may still be able to transfer the permit without their declaration. Contact the Integrated Permitting Service (IPS) to discuss this:

  • Email: psc‐waterquality@environment‐agency.gov.uk (opens in new tab)
  • Telephone: 020 8474 8938

You will need to give evidence that you cannot trace one or all of the permit holders.

pages.title: Exemptions for surface water discharges

components.name: ecNIfj
components.title: Html
components.content:
Surface water discharges are exempt if they meet all of the following criteria:

  • the sewage is domestic only – check the definition of domestic sewage (opens in new tab)
  • the discharge started before 6 April 2010 and met standards when it was first made – if your discharge has changed since this date, your discharge will not be exempt
  • you treat the sewage with a sewage treatment plant (also know as a package sewage plant)
  • sewage from the treatment plant discharges to inland freshwater (such as a river, stream, seasonally dry ditch, pond, lake or canal), coastal waters or territorial waters
  • you discharge 5 cubic metres per day or less from the treatment plant – use the discharge calculator (opens in new tab) to check
  • an approved contractor operates, maintains and empties your treatment plant on a regular basis
  • your treatment system is not causing any pollution

If you are unsure if your discharge meets the exemption criteria, contact your service engineer. Check the British Water’s list of accredited service engineers (opens in new tab)

components.name: QzKwOG
components.title: Does your surface water discharge meet the exemption criteria?

pages.title: Exemptions for groundwater discharges

components.name: tZXTBz
components.title: Html
components.content:
Groundwater discharges are exempt if they meet all of the following criteria:

  • the sewage is domestic only – check the definition of domestic sewage (opens in new tab)
  • the discharge started before 6 April 2010 and met standards when it was first made – if your discharge has changed since this date, your discharge will not be exempt
  • you treat the sewage with a septic tank and infiltration system or a sewage treatment plant and infiltration system
  • sewage from the treatment plant or septic tank discharges to ground
  • you discharge 2 cubic metres per day or less from the treatment plant – use the discharge calculator (opens in new tab) to check
  • an approved contractor operates, maintains and empties your treatment plant on a regular basis
  • the discharge is not within groundwater source protection zone – find out more about groundwater source protection zones (opens in new tab)

If you are unsure if your discharge meets the exemption criteria, contact your service engineer. Check the British Water’s list of accredited service engineers (opens in new tab)

components.title: Does your groundwater discharge meet the exemption criteria?

components.name: MiCNYs

components.hint: Briefly explain why the waste water discharge has stopped, such as because of connection to the sewer.

pages.title: What will happen next

components.name: iBJQFc
components.title: Html
components.content:
You should continue to the end of the form to submit your answers.

The Environment Agency will then try to contact the current occupier of the site. The occupier may request a permit transfer from you if they still need the permit.

If the occupier does not respond, the Environment Agency will get in touch about surrendering your permit.

pages.title: Transferring your permit to a new operator

components.name: uGwkAA
components.title: Html
components.content:
To transfer the permit into the new operator's name, you will need to:

  1. Continue to the end of this form to submit your answers.
  2. Complete the Notification for an environmental permit: part D1, notification of transfer (opens in new tab) form.

Both you and the existing permit holder will need to complete part D1.

The Environment Agency will send you a transfer notification once the permit is in the new operator's name.
